summary.long: Joshua is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: After Moses, the servant of the Lord, had died, the Lord spoke to Nun’s son Joshua, announcing to him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “My servant Moses is dead. Now get ready to cross the Jordan River—you and all the people—to the land that I’m giving the Israelis.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’m giving you every place where the sole of your foot falls, just as I promised Moses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your territorial border will extend from the wilderness to the Lebanon Mountains, to the river—that great River Euphrates—all the land of the Hittites—as far as the Mediterranean Sea where the sun sets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No one will be victorious against you for the rest of your life. I’ll be with you just like I was with Moses—I’ll neither fail you nor abandon you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Be strong and courageous, because you’ll be leading this people to inherit the land that I promised to give their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Only be strong and very courageous to ensure that you obey all the instructions that my servant Moses gave you—turn neither to the right nor to the left from it—so that you may succeed wherever you go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This set of instructions is not to cease being a part of your conversations. Meditate on it day and night, so that you may be careful to carry out everything that’s written in it, for then you’ll prosper and succeed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ve commanded you, haven’t I? Be strong and courageous. Don’t be fearful or discouraged, because the Lord your God is with you wherever you go.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joshua gave orders to the officials of the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go through the camp,” he said, “and command the people, ‘Prepare provisions for yourselves, because within three days you’ll be crossing the Jordan River to take possession of the land that the Lord your God is giving you—so go get it!’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joshua told the descendants of Reuben, the descendants of Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Remember what Moses commanded you when he said, ‘The Lord your God will provide you rest, as well as this land.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your wives, your young children, and your livestock will remain in the land that Moses gave you on this side of the Jordan River, but you and all your warriors will cross, ready for battle, in full view of your relatives, and you will help them
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: until the Lord gives relief to your relatives, as he did to you. Then they’ll take the land that the Lord your God is giving them as their inheritance. You’ll return to the land of your heritage and receive the inheritance that Moses the servant of the Lord gave you on the east side of the Jordan River, in the direction of the sunrise.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “We’ll do everything that you commanded,” they replied. “We’ll go wherever you send us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We’ll listen and obey you in everything, just like we did with Moses. Only may the Lord your God be with you, just as he was with Moses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Anyone who rebels against what you say and doesn’t listen to your words regarding everything that you command will be executed. Only be strong and courageous.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, Nun’s son Joshua sent two men from the Acacia groves as undercover scouts. He told them, “Go and look over the land. Pay special attention to Jericho.” So they went out, came to the house of a prostitute named Rahab, and lodged there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king of Jericho was told, “Look! Israeli men arrived tonight to scout out the land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king of Jericho sent for Rahab and ordered her, “Bring out the men who came to visit you and lodged in your house, because they’ve come to scout out the entire land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the woman had taken the two men and hid them. So she replied, “The men really did come to me, but I didn’t know from where they came.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At dusk, when it was time to close the city gates, the men left. I don’t know where the men went. Go after them quickly, and you might overtake them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But she had taken them up to the roof and had hidden them among stalks of flax that she had laid out in order on the roof.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the men pursued them along the road that leads to the fords of the Jordan River. As soon as the search party had left, they shut the city gate after them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Before the scouts had lain down, she went up to them on the roof
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I’m really convinced that the Lord has given you the land,” she said, “because we’re overwhelmed with fear of you. All the other inhabitants of the land are demoralized at your presence,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because we heard how the Lord dried up the water of the Reed Sea right in front of you as you were coming out of Egypt, and what you did to the two kings of the Amorites who were on the other side of the Jordan River—to Sihon and Og—whom you completely destroyed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When we heard these reports, we all became terrified and discouraged because of you, for the Lord your God is God in heaven above and on the earth beneath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now therefore, since I’ve treated you so kindly, please swear in the name of the Lord that you’ll also be kind to my father’s household by giving me this sure sign:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Spare my father, my mother, and my brothers and sisters, along with everyone who belongs with them so we won’t be killed.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the men told her, “Our life for yours—even to death—if you don’t betray this mission of ours. Then when the Lord gives us this land, we’ll treat you graciously and faithfully.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So she let them down by a rope through the window, since her house was built into the town wall where she lived.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She told them, “Go out to the hill country, so the search party won’t find you, and hide for three days. After that, you may go on your own way.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men replied, “We’ll be free from our commitment to you to which you’ve obligated us
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: when we invade the land, if you don’t tie this rope made with red cords in the window through which you let us down, and if you don’t gather your father, your mother, your brothers, and all of the rest of your father’s household into your house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everyone who leaves through the doors of your house into the street will be responsible for his own death, but we’ll be responsible for anyone who remains with you in the house if even so much as a hand is laid on him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you report this incident, we’ll be free from the oath to which you’ve made us swear.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Since you put it that way,” she replied, “I agree.” After she sent them on their way and they had left, she tied the red cord in the window.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The scouts left for the hill country and remained there for three days until the search party returned. The search party searched the entire road, but was unable to find them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later, the two men returned from the hill country, crossed over the Jordan River, approached Nun’s son Joshua, and told him everything that had happened to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They reported to Joshua, “The Lord really has given the entire land into our control. The inhabitants of the land have melted away right in front of us!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joshua got up early the next morning. Accompanied by all the Israelis, he set out from the Acacia groves and arrived at the Jordan River, where they encamped before crossing it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Three days later, the officers went throughout the camp,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: giving orders to the people. They said, “When you see the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord your God being carried by the Levitical priests, then get up, leave where you are, and follow it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Be sure to keep a distance of about 2,000 cubits between you and it. Don’t come near it, so you can be certain where you’re going, since you haven’t passed this way before.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joshua addressed the people: “Consecrate yourselves, because tomorrow the Lord will do marvelous things among you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, Joshua instructed the priests, “Take up the Ark of the Covenant and cross over ahead of the people.” So they took up the Ark of the Covenant and went on ahead of the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At this point, the Lord told Joshua, “Today I’m going to exalt you in the sight of all Israel, so they’ll be sure that I’m going to be with you just as I was with Moses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Give this command to the priests who are carrying the Ark of the Covenant: ‘When you arrive at the water of the Jordan River, stand still in the Jordan.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joshua told the Israelis, “Come here and listen to what the Lord your God has to say.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joshua continued, “This is how you’ll know that the living God really is among you: he’s going to remove the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Hivites, the Perizzites, the Girgashites, the Amorites, and the Jebusites right in front of you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Look! The Ark of the Covenant of the Lord of whole the earth is crossing ahead of you into the Jordan River.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So take for yourselves twelve men from the tribes of Israel, one man from each tribe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the soles of the feet of the priests who carry the ark of the Lord, the Lord of the whole earth, touch the water in the Jordan River, the water that feeds the Jordan will be cut off from above and they’ll stand still in a single location.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the people set out from their tents to cross the Jordan River, with the priests carrying the Ark of the Covenant in full view of the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the priests who carried the ark entered the Jordan River, as their feet touched the water’s edge (The Jordan River overflows all of its banks daily during the harvest season.),
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the water flowing downstream from above stood still in a single location, a great distance away at Adam, a city near Zarethan. The water that flowed south toward the sea in the Arabah (that is, the Dead Sea) was completely cut off. So the people crossed opposite Jericho.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests who were carrying the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord stood firm on dry ground in the middle of the Jordan River, while all Israel crossed on dry ground until the entire nation had finished crossing the Jordan River.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As soon as the entire nation had completed its crossing of the Jordan, the Lord spoke to Joshua. He said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Gather together twelve men from the people—one man from each tribe—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and tell them, ‘Pick up twelve stones from the middle of the Jordan where the priests’ feet were standing, bring them along with you, and put them down where you camp tonight.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joshua called the twelve men whom he had chosen from the people of Israel, one man from each tribe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joshua told them, “Cross over again in front of the ark of the Lord your God into the middle of the Jordan River. Then each of you pick up a stone on his shoulder with which to build a memorial, one for each of the tribes of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Let this serve as a sign among you, so that when your children ask in times to come, ‘What do these stones mean to you,’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then you’ll say to them, ‘Because the waters of the Jordan River were cut off in front of the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord. When it crossed the Jordan River, the waters of the Jordan were cut off.’ So these stones will become a memorial to the Israelis forever.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelis did just as Joshua commanded. They took up twelve stones from the middle of the Jordan River—just as the Lord had spoken to Joshua—according to the number of the tribes of the Israelis, and they carried them over to where they would be pitching camp, and they put them down there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joshua set up twelve stones in the middle of the Jordan River at the location where the feet of the priests who carried the Ark of the Covenant had been standing, and they remain there to this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests who were carrying the ark stood in the middle of the Jordan River until everything had been done in accordance with what the Lord had commanded Joshua to speak to the people and with everything that Moses had commanded Joshua. So the people hurried and crossed over.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all of the people had completed their crossing, the ark of the Lord and the priests crossed over in full view of the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Just as Moses had directed, the descendants of Reuben, the descendants of Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh crossed over, dressed in battle regalia, in full view of the other Israelis.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: About 40,000 soldiers equipped to do battle in the Lord’s presence crossed over to the desert plains of Jericho.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That day, the Lord exalted Joshua in the presence of all Israel so that they revered him just as they had revered Moses throughout his life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the Lord had told Joshua,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Command the priests who carry the Ark of the Testimony to come up from the Jordan River.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joshua ordered the priests, “Come up from the Jordan River.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As soon as the priests who were carrying the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord had come up from the middle of the Jordan River, and the soles of the priests’ feet came up to dry ground, the water of the Jordan River returned to normal, covering its banks as it had done so before.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people came up from the Jordan River on the tenth day of the first month and camped at Gilgal on the eastern outskirts of Jericho.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joshua set up the twelve stones that they had removed from the Jordan River at Gilgal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he told the Israelis, “When your descendants ask their parents in years to come, ‘What is the meaning of these stones?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: you are to tell your descendants: ‘Israel crossed this Jordan River on dry ground
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because the Lord your God dried up the water of the Jordan River right in front of you, until you had crossed over, just as the Lord your God had done to the Reed Sea—which he had dried up in front of us until we had crossed it also.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do this so that all of the people of the earth may know how strong the power of the Lord is, and so that you may fear the Lord your God every day.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the Amorite kings who lived across the Jordan River to the west and all the Canaanite kings by the Mediterranean Sea became discouraged as soon as they heard that the Lord had dried up the water of the Jordan River for the people of Israel until they had crossed it. They no longer had a will to fight because of the people of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time the Lord told Joshua, “Make for yourselves some flint knives and circumcise the Israelis who haven’t been circumcised yet.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joshua made some flint knives and circumcised the Israelis at Gibeath-haaraloth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joshua circumcised them because all of the males among the people who came out of Egypt—that is, all the warriors—had died during their journey through the wilderness following their departure from Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Although everyone who had left Egypt had been circumcised, nevertheless all the people born during the journey after their departure from Egypt had not been circumcised.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelis traveled 40 years in the wilderness until the entire nation—that is, the warriors who had departed from Egypt—had perished because they hadn’t listened to the voice of the Lord. The Lord had promised them that he would not let them see the land that he had sworn to give us, a land that flows with milk and honey.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As a result, it was their descendants, whom he raised up to take their place, that Joshua circumcised. They had remained uncircumcised, because they had not been circumcised during their journey.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the circumcision of the entire nation was complete, they remained in their places within the camp until they were healed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord told Joshua, “Today I have rolled the disgrace of Egypt away from you.” That’s why that place is called “Gilgal” to this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While the Israelis remained encamped at Gilgal on the plains of Jericho, they observed the Passover during the evening of the fourteenth day of the month.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the day following Passover—on that exact day—they ate the produce of the land, unleavened cakes and parched grain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The manna ceased on the day they ate the produce of the land. Since the Israelis no longer received manna, they ate crops from the land of Canaan that year.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now it happened that while Joshua was near Jericho, he looked up and much to his amazement, he saw a man standing in front of him, holding a drawn sword in his hand! Joshua approached him and asked him, “Are you one of us, or are you with our enemies?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Neither,” he answered. “I have come as commander of the Lord’s Army.”
Joshua immediately fell on his face to the earth and worshipped, saying to him, “Lord, what do you have for your servant by way of command?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The commander of the Lord’s Army replied to Joshua, “Remove your sandals from your feet, because the place where you’re standing is holy.” So Joshua did so.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, Jericho was fortified inside and out because of the Israelis. Nobody could leave or enter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord told Joshua, “Look! I have given Jericho over to your control, along with its kings and valiant soldiers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: March around the city, all the soldiers circling the city once. Do this for six days,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: with seven priests carrying in front of the ark seven trumpets made from rams’ horns. On the seventh day march around the city seven times while the priests blow their trumpets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they sound a long blast with the ram’s horn, as soon as you hear the sound of the trumpet, then the entire army is to cry out loud, the city wall will collapse, and then all of the soldiers are to charge straight ahead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Nun’s son Joshua called for the priests. “Pick up the Ark of the Covenant,” he told them, “and have seven priests carry seven trumpets made from rams’ horns in front of the ark of the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He told the army, “Go out and encircle the city. Have the armed men march out in front of the ark of the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And so, just as Joshua had commanded, seven of the priests went forward, carrying the seven trumpets made of rams’ horns in the Lord’s presence, blowing the trumpets while the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord followed them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Armed men preceded the priests who were blowing the trumpets, and a rear guard followed the ark, while the trumpets continued to blow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joshua issued orders to the army: “You are not to shout or even let your voice be heard. Don’t utter a word until I tell you to shout. Then shout!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the ark of the Lord was taken once around the city, then they went back to camp and spent the night there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joshua got up early the next morning, and the priests picked up the ark of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The seven priests who carried the seven trumpets made from rams’ horns preceded the ark of the Lord, blowing their trumpets constantly. The armed men preceded them, and the rear guard followed the ark of the Lord, while the trumpets continued to blow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the second day they marched around the city once and then went back to camp. They did this for six days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They rose early at dawn on the seventh day and marched around the city seven times, just as they had before, except that on that day only they marched around the city seven times.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As they completed the seventh time, after the priests had blown the trumpets, Joshua told the army, “Shout, because the Lord has given you the city!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The city—along with everything in it—is to be turned over to the Lord for destruction. Only Rahab the prostitute and everyone who is with her in her house may live, because she hid the scouts we sent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now as for you, everything has been turned over for destruction. Don’t covet or take any of these things. Otherwise, you’ll make the camp of Israel itself an object worthy of destruction, and bring trouble on it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But everything made of silver and gold, and vessels made of bronze and iron are set apart to the Lord. They are to go into the treasury of the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the army shouted and the trumpets were blown again. As soon as the army heard the sound of the trumpets, they shouted loudly and the wall collapsed. The army charged straight ahead into the city and captured it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They turned over everyone in the city for destruction and executed them, including both men and women, young and old, and oxen, sheep, and donkeys.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joshua told the two men who had scouted the land, “Go into the prostitute’s home and bring her out of it, along with everyone who is with her, just as you promised her.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the young men who had been scouts went in and brought Rahab out, along with her father, her mother, her brothers, and everyone else who was with her. They brought her entire family out and set them outside the camp of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the army set fire to the city and to everything in it, except that they reserved the silver, gold, and vessels of bronze and iron for the treasury of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Joshua spared Rahab the prostitute, along with her family and everyone who was with her. Her family has lived in Israel ever since, because she hid the scouts whom Joshua sent to observe Jericho.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Joshua made everyone take the following oath at that time. He said:
“Cursed in the presence of the Lord is the man
    who restores and rebuilds this city of Jericho!
He will lay its foundation at the cost of his firstborn,
    and at the cost of his youngest he will set up its gates.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord was with Joshua, and as a result, Joshua’s reputation spread throughout the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later, the Israelis broke their promise regarding the things that had been turned over to destruction. Carmi’s son Achan, grandson of Zabdi and great-grandson of Zerah from the tribe of Judah, appropriated some of the things that had been turned over to destruction. As a result, the Lord became angry with the Israelis.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, Joshua had sent some soldiers from Jericho to Ai, which was near Beth-aven, east of Bethel. He ordered them, “Go up and scout the land.” So the soldiers went up and scouted Ai and
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
returned to Joshua.
“Not all of the people need to go up,” they reported. “Only about two or three thousand men should attack Ai. Since they are so few, don’t make all of the army work hard up there.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So about three thousand went up there, but they ran away from the men of Ai.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men of Ai killed about 36 of them, pursuing them outside the city gates as far as Shebarim, killing them as they descended. As a result, the army became terrified and lost their confidence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At this, Joshua tore his clothes, fell down to the ground on his face before the ark of the Lord until evening—he and the leaders of Israel—and they covered their heads with dust.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Lord God,” Joshua asked, “Why have you brought this people across the Jordan River? To hand us over to the Amorites so we’ll be destroyed? Wouldn’t it have been better for us to be content to settle on the other side of the Jordan?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Lord, what am I to say, now that Israel has run away from its enemies?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Canaanites and all the inhabitants of the land will hear of this, will surround us, and eliminate us from the earth! Then what will you do about your great reputation?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Get up!” the Lord replied to Joshua. “Why have you fallen on your face?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel has sinned. They broke my covenant that I commanded them by taking some of the things that had been turned over to destruction. They have stolen, have been deceitful, and have stored what they stole among their own belongings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelis have been unable to stand before their enemies. They’re turning their backs and running from their enemies because they themselves have been turned over to destruction. I will not be with you anymore unless you destroy these things that have been turned over to destruction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So get up and sanctify the people. Tell them, ‘Sanctify yourselves in preparation for tomorrow, because this is what the Lord God of Israel, says: “There are things turned over to destruction among you, Israel. You won’t be able to defeat your enemies until you remove what has been turned over to destruction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Tomorrow morning you are to come forward tribe by tribe. The tribe that the Lord selects is to come forward by tribes, the tribe that the Lord selects is to come forward by households, and the household that the Lord selects is to come forward one by one.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The one selected as having taken what has been turned over to destruction is to be incinerated, along with everything that pertains to him, because he has transgressed against the covenant of the Lord and committed an outrageous thing in Israel.”’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joshua got up early that morning, brought Israel near tribe by tribe, and the tribe of Judah was selected.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He brought near the tribes of Judah, and the Zerahite tribe was selected. Then he brought near the Zerahite tribe family by family, and the household of Zabdi was selected.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Next, he brought near his household one by one, and Carmi’s son Achan, grandson of Zabdi and great-grandson of Zerah, was selected from the tribe of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joshua then spoke to Achan, “My son, give glory and praise to the Lord God of Israel. Tell me right now what you did. Don’t hide anything.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Achan answered Joshua, “It’s true. I’m the one who sinned against the Lord God of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I noticed among the war spoils a beautiful mantle from Shinar, 200 shekels of silver, and a bar of gold weighing 50 shekels. Because I wanted them, I took them, and they’re buried in the ground inside my tent. The silver is underneath.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joshua sent some messengers, who ran to the tent. And there it was, hidden in the tent with the silver underneath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They took the things from the tent that had been turned over to destruction, brought them to Joshua and all of the Israelis, and laid them out in the presence of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joshua, with all Israel accompanying him, took Zerah’s son Achan, along with the silver, the mantle, the gold, his sons, his daughters, his oxen, his donkeys, his sheep, his tent, and everything that belonged to him to the Valley of Achor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joshua announced, “Why did you bring trouble to us? Today the Lord is bringing trouble to you!” So all Israel stoned him to death, incinerated them, and buried them with stones,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: piling up a large mound of boulders that remains to this day. After this, the Lord turned his burning anger away, and that is why that place is called “the Valley of Achor” to this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord then told Joshua, “Don’t be afraid or lose heart! Take all the fighting men with you, and go up right now to Ai. Take note that I have handed over the king of Ai into your control, along with his people, his city, and his land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do to Ai and its king as you did to Jericho and its king, but take its spoil and its livestock as war booty for yourselves. Set an ambush around the city.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joshua and all of the fighting men prepared to go out against Ai. Joshua selected 30,000 valiant warriors and sent them out by night,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: telling them, “Pay attention now! You are to set up an ambush around the city. Don’t go very far from the city, and all of you remain on alert.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I and all of the army with me will advance upon the city. When they come out after us like they did before, we’ll run away from them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They’ll come after us until we’ve drawn them away from the city, because they’ll say, ‘They’re running away from us just like they did before.’ While we’re running away from them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: you get up from the ambush and seize the city, because the Lord your God will give it into your control.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When you’ve taken the city, set it on fire, just as the Lord ordered. Look! These are your orders!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So Joshua sent them out, and they set up an ambush between Bethel and Ai, to the west of Ai.
Joshua spent that night in the camp among the army.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the morning, Joshua got up early, mustered his army, and set off for Ai, accompanied by the elders of Israel in full view of the army.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The entire fighting force with him attacked, approaching the city, and camped on the north side of Ai, with a ravine between them and Ai.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Taking about 5,000 men, he set them in ambush between Bethel and Ai to the west of the city,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: stationing their forces with its main encampment north of the city and its rear guard to the west. Joshua spent that night in the valley.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the king of Ai saw what had happened, he and his army quickly got up early and went out to meet Israel in battle. He and all his people met at the place adjacent to the desert plain. But he didn’t know about the ambush that had been set for him on the other side of the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because Joshua and the entire fighting force of Israel pretended to lose the battle by running away in front of them toward the wilderness,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: everyone in the city followed after them. As they pursued Joshua, they were drawn away from the town.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There wasn’t a single man left in Ai or Bethel who didn’t run out after Israel. They left the city open and pursued Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord told Joshua, “Stretch out the battle lance that’s in your hand toward Ai, because I will give it into your control.” So Joshua stretched out the battle lance that was in his hand toward the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As soon as he stretched out his hand, the troops in ambush quickly got up from their place of hiding and attacked. They entered the city, seized it, and immediately set it on fire.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the men of Ai looked back behind them—and all of a sudden!—smoke from the city was rising into the sky. They were unable to run in any direction, because the Israelis who had fled toward the wilderness had turned around to attack their pursuers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Joshua and the entire fighting force of Israel observed that the men who had been in ambush had seized the city and that the smoke from the city was rising, they turned around and attacked the men of Ai.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the others came out from the city against them, so the men of Ai were surrounded by the Israelis, some on one side and some on the other. Israel attacked them until no one was left to survive or escape.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the king of Ai was taken alive and brought to Joshua.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Israel had completed executing all of the residents of Ai in the open wilderness where they had chased them, and after all of them—to the very last of them—had been killed by swords, the entire fighting force of Israel returned to Ai and attacked it with swords.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The total of all who fell that day, including men and women, was 12,000—the entire population of Ai.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joshua did not cease his attack until he had completely destroyed every inhabitant of Ai.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel took only the livestock and the spoil of that city as their war booty, in accordance with what the Lord had commanded to Joshua.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joshua burned Ai, turning it into a permanent mound of ruins, and it remains so to this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He hanged the king of Ai on a tree until dusk, and at sunset Joshua ordered his body brought down from the tree and laid at the entrance to the gate of the town. There he raised over it a large mound of stones, which stands there to this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joshua built an altar to the Lord God of Israel, on Mount Ebal,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: just the way Moses the servant of the Lord had commanded the Israelis in the Book of the Law of Moses: “…an altar of uncut stones that hasn’t been worked with iron tools…” and they offered burnt offerings to the Lord on it, along with peace offerings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There Joshua inscribed on stones a copy of the Law of Moses that Moses had presented to the Israelis.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All Israel, both foreigners and citizens, together with their elders, officers, and judges, stood on opposite sides of the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord. Half stood in front of Mount Gerizim and half stood in front of Mount Ebal, just as Moses, the Lord’s servant had commanded at the first, so that they could bless the people of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Afterwards, Joshua read all the words of the Law—both the blessings and the curses—according to everything written in the Book of the Law.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There wasn’t one word of everything Moses had commanded that Joshua did not read in front of the entire assembly of Israel, including the women, their little ones, and the foreigners who lived among them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Eventually all the kings who reigned in the hill country across the Jordan River and in the low-lying coastlands of the Mediterranean Sea facing Lebanon heard about this. So the Hittites, the Amorites, the Canaanites, the Perizzites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: united together as one to fight against both Joshua and Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when the inhabitants of Gibeon heard what Joshua had done to Jericho and Ai,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: they took the initiative by preparing their provisions shrewdly: they took tattered sacks for their donkeys, worn-out, torn, and mended wineskins,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: worn-out, patched sandals for their feet, and worn-out clothes. All of their food was dried out and covered in mold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they approached Joshua in the camp at Gilgal and addressed him and the Israelis, “We’ve arrived from a distant country, so please make a treaty with us right now.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Israelis responded to the Hivites, “Perhaps you live in our midst. If this is so, how can we make a treaty with you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So they responded to Joshua, “We are your servants.”
Joshua asked them, “Who are you? And where did you come from?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They answered, “Your servants have arrived from a very distant land, because of the reputation of the Lord your God, because we’ve heard a report about all that he did in Egypt,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: along with all of what he did to the two Amorite kings who were beyond the Jordan River—that is, to King Sihon of Heshbon and to King Og of Bashan, who lived in Ashtaroth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So our leaders and all of the inhabitants of our country told us, ‘Take provisions along with you for your journey, go to meet them, and tell them, “We are your servants. Come now and make a treaty with us.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Look at our bread: it was still warm when we took it from our houses as our food for our journey on the very day we set out to come to you. But now, look how it’s dry and moldy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And these wineskins were new when we filled them, but look—now they’re cracked. And our clothes and sandals are worn out from our very long journey.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the leaders of Israel sampled their provisions, but did not ask the Lord about it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They made a treaty with them, guaranteeing their lives with a covenant, and the leaders of the congregation confirmed it with an oath to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But three days after they had made the treaty with them, they learned that they were their neighbors and were living in their midst.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Israelis set out for their cities and three days later they reached their cities of Gibeon, Chephirah, Beeroth, and Kiriath-jearim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelis did not attack them, because the leaders of the congregation had made an oath with them in the name of the Lord, the God of Israel. Nevertheless, the entire congregation grumbled against their leaders.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all of the leaders spoke to the entire congregation, “We have sworn to them in the name of the Lord, the God of Israel, and we cannot touch them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So this is what we’ll do to them: we’ll let them live, so that wrath won’t come upon us because of the oath that we swore to them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The leaders told them, “Let them live.” So they became wood cutters and water carriers for the entire congregation, which is what the leaders had decided concerning them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joshua summoned the Gibeonites and asked them, “Why did you deceive us by saying ‘We live far away from you,’ even though you were, in fact, living in our midst?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now therefore you are under a curse. Some of you will always be slaves, wood cutters, and water carriers for the house of my God.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They replied to Joshua, “Because your servants had been informed that the Lord your God had certainly commanded his servant Moses to give you the entire land and to destroy all of the inhabitants of the land before you. So we were terrified for our lives because of you. That’s why we did this.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now we’re under your control: do to us as it seems good and right in your opinion.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So this is what Joshua did for them: he saved them from the Israelis, and they did not kill them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, on that very day Joshua made them become wood cutters and water carriers for the congregation and for the Lord’s altar in the place that he should choose, and this tradition continues to this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Adoni-zedek of Jerusalem eventually heard how Joshua had conquered Ai, utterly destroying it, doing to Ai and its king the same thing that he had done to Jericho and its king, and how the inhabitants of Gibeon had made peace with Israel and were now living among them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they were terrified, since Gibeon was a large city, comparable to one of the royal cities, was larger than Ai, and all of its men had been warriors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So King Adoni-zedek of Jerusalem sent word to King Hoham of Hebron, King Piram of Jarmuth, King Japhia of Lachish, and King Debir of Eglon. He told them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Come over and help me, and let’s attack Gibeon, because it made a peace treaty with Joshua and the Israelis.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the five kings of the Amorites—the king of Jerusalem, the king of Hebron, the king of Jarmuth, the king of Lachish, and the king of Eglon—gathered their armies together and advanced with all of their armies toward Gideon, camped there, and laid siege to it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Gibeonites sent word to Joshua at his camp in Gilgal: “Don’t abandon your servants. Come quickly, save us, and help us, because all of the kings of the Amorites who live in the hill country have attacked us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joshua went up from Gilgal, along with his entire fighting force of mighty warriors with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord told Joshua, “Don’t fear them, because I have handed them over to you. Not one of them will withstand you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So after an all-night march from Gilgal, Joshua attacked them by surprise.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord threw the Amorites into a panic right in front of the army of Israel, which then slaughtered many of them at Gibeon. The Israeli army chased them along the road that goes up to Beth-horon, striking them down as far as Azekah and Makkedah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While they were fleeing in front of Israel and descending the slope of Beth-horon, the Lord rained down huge hailstones on them as far as Azekah, and they died. More died because of the hailstones than were killed by the Israelis in battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Later that day, Joshua spoke to the Lord while the Lord was delivering the Amorites to the Israelis. This is what he said in the presence of Israel:
“Sun, be still over Gibeon!
    Moon, stand in place in the Aijalon Valley!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So the sun remained still
    and the moon stood in place
        until the nation settled their score with their enemies.
This is recorded, is it not, in the book of Jashar?
The sun stood in place
    in the middle of the sky
and seemed not to be in a hurry
    to set for nearly an entire day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There has never been a day like it before or since, when the Lord listened to the voice of a man, because the Lord was fighting on behalf of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, Joshua returned to the camp at Gilgal with the entire fighting force of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, the five kings had fled and hidden themselves inside a cave at Makkedah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joshua was informed, “The five kings have been discovered hiding in the cave at Makkedah.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joshua gave an order, “Roll large stones up against the mouth of the cave and assign men to stand guard there,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but don’t stay there yourselves. Instead, pursue your enemies and attack them from behind. Don’t allow them to enter their cities, because the Lord your God has delivered them into your control.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now it came about that after Joshua and the Israelis had finished the battle, destroying and scattering their survivors, who retreated into their fortified cities,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the entire army returned safely to Joshua’s encampment at Makkedah. No one could speak so much as a single word against any of the Israelis.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joshua gave this order: “Unseal the mouth of the cave and bring out these five kings to me from the cave.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they did. They brought out these five kings to him from within the cave: the king of Jerusalem, the king of Hebron, the king of Jarmuth, the king of Lachish, and the king of Eglon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they had brought these kings out to Joshua, Joshua called for all the men of Israel and spoke to the leaders of the men who had gone out to war along with him, “Come close and put your feet on the necks of these kings.” So they came near and put their feet on their necks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joshua told the army, “Don’t fear or be dismayed! Be strong and courageous, because this is how the Lord will treat all of your enemies whom you fight.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, Joshua struck those kings down, executing them, and hanged them on five gallows until sunset.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When evening had come, Joshua gave a command to remove the bodies from the gallows and bury them in the cave where they had hidden. The army sealed the mouth of the cave with large stones that remain there to this very day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joshua captured Makkedah that very day, and attacked both it and its king with swords, utterly destroying it along with every person in it, leaving no survivors. He dealt with the king of Makkedah the same way he had dealt with the king of Jericho.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Afterward, Joshua and all of Israel passed on from Makkedah to Libnah, where they fought against Libnah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord gave both it and its king into the control of Israel, and Joshua executed both its king and every person in it with swords, leaving no survivors. He dealt with the king the same way he had dealt with the king of Jericho.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joshua and all of Israel passed from Libnah to Lachish, camped near it, and attacked it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord gave Lachish into the control of Israel, and Joshua captured it the next day. He declared war on the city and executed everyone in it, the same way he had treated Libnah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Horam king of Gezer appeared to help Lachish. So Joshua attacked him and his army, until he left no one remaining.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, Joshua, accompanied by all of Israel, proceeded from Lachish to Eglon, laid siege to it, and attacked it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They captured it on that day, attacking it in battle. Then Joshua completely destroyed it that day, the same way he had dealt with Lachish.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joshua, accompanied by all of Israel, left Eglon for Hebron, where they attacked it,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: captured it, and executed its inhabitants—its king, all of its cities, and every person in it, leaving no one remaining, the same way he had dealt with Eglon. He completely destroyed it, along with everyone in it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joshua returned, accompanied by the entire fighting force of Israel, to Debir, where they attacked it,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: captured it, its king, and all of its villages. They executed them, totally destroying it and everyone in it, leaving no one remaining. He dealt with Debir and its king just as he had dealt with Hebron, treating them the same way he had dealt with Libnah and its king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joshua conquered the entire land, the hill country, the Negev, the Shephelah, and the wilderness highlands, along with all of their kings. He left none of them remaining, but completely destroyed every living person, just as the Lord God of Israel had commanded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joshua conquered them from Kadesh-barnea to Gaza, including the entire territory of Goshen as far as Gibeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joshua conquered all of these kings and their territories in one campaign, because the Lord God of Israel fought for Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joshua returned to the camp at Gilgal, along with the entire fighting force of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When King Jabin of Hazor heard all of this, he sent word to Jobab king of Madon, to the king of Shimron, to the king of Achshaph,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and to the kings in the north, in the hill country, in the plain south of Chinnereth, in the Shephelah, and in the hills of Dor toward the west,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: to the eastern and western Canaanites—the Amorites, the Hittites, the Perizzites, the Jebusites in the hill country, and the Hivites below Hermon in the territory of Mizpah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they went out, they and all of their armies with them—a multitude as numerous as the sand on the seashore—accompanied by many horses and chariots.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After all these kings had gathered together, they went out and camped together at the waters of Merom to fight Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord told Joshua, “Don’t be afraid of them, because tomorrow about this time I am giving them all to you—dead—in the presence of Israel. Hamstring their horses and incinerate their chariots.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joshua and his entire fighting force approached them suddenly by the waters of Merom and attacked them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord handed them over to the control of Israel, who defeated them and chased them as far as Greater Sidon and east as far as the Mizpah Valley. They attacked them until none remained.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joshua dealt with them just as the Lord had told him: he hamstrung their horses and incinerated their chariots.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joshua then turned back and captured Hazor, executing its king, because Hazor used to be the head of all of those kingdoms.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They executed all of the people who lived in it, completely destroying it and leaving no one alive. Then he burned Hazor in fire.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joshua captured and annihilated all of these cities, along with their kings, completely destroying them, just as Moses the servant of the Lord had commanded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, Israel did not burn any of the cities that had been built on mounds of ruins, except for Hazor only, which Joshua burned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelis took the spoils of war from these cities, along with their livestock, but they executed every human being until they had completely destroyed them, leaving no one alive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joshua did just what the Lord had commanded his servant Moses and just what Moses had commanded him, leaving nothing unfinished.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joshua conquered all of these territories: the hill country, all of the Negev, the entire land of Goshen with its foothills, the plains of Jordan, and the mountains of Israel with its foothills
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: from Mount Halak and the ascent toward Seir, including as far as Baal-gad in the Lebanon Valley that lies at the foot of Mount Hermon. Joshua captured all of their kings, struck them down, and put them to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joshua fought an extended campaign against all those kings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There wasn’t a single city that made a peace accord with the Israelis, except the Hivites who lived in Gibeon. The Israelis captured all the rest in battle,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because the Lord had hardened their hearts so they would fight Israel in war, be completely destroyed without mercy, and be completely wiped out, as the Lord had commanded Moses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time Joshua came and annihilated the Anakim from the hill country, that is, from Hebron, Debir, and Anab, as well as from all the hill country of Judah and Israel. Joshua completely destroyed them along with their cities.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: None of the Anakim remained in the land belonging to the Israelis—they remained only in Gaza, in Gath, and in Ashdod.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joshua conquered the entire land, in accordance with everything that the Lord had told Moses. Joshua presented it as an inheritance to Israel, dividing it according to tribal allotments. Then the land enjoyed rest from war.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is a list of the kings who ruled the land that the Israelis conquered, and whose territories they took on the other side of the Jordan River toward the east, from the Arnon River to Mount Hermon, along with the entire eastern Jordan plain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sihon king of the Amorites lived in Heshbon and ruled from Aroer, which is located on the edge of the Arnon River from the middle of the valley, including half of Gilead as far as Wadi Jabbok, the border of the Ammonites,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and toward the Arabah as far as the Sea of Galilee to the east, as far as the Arabah Sea (that is, the Dead Sea) to the east as one travels in the direction of Beth-jeshimoth, and to the south as far as the foothills of Pisgah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The territory of Og king of Bashan was conquered. He was one of the last of the Rephaim, and lived at Ashtaroth and Edrei,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ruling over Mount Hermon, Salecah, and all of Bashan as far as the border of the descendants of Geshur, the descendants of Maacath, and half of Gilead to the border of Sihon king of Heshbon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses, the servant of the Lord, and the Israelis defeated them. Then Moses, the servant of the Lord, gave it to the descendants of Reuben, the descendants of Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh as their inheritance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is a list of the kings of the land whom Joshua and the Israelis defeated beyond the Jordan River toward the west, from Baal-gad in the Lebanon valley as far as Mount Halak, which rises in the direction of Seir. Joshua gave it to Israel, distributing it according to their tribal divisions as their inheritance,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: in the mountain regions, in the Arabah, on the foothills, in the wilderness, in the Negev; that is, the Hittites, the Amorites, the Canaanites, the Perizzites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king of Jericho: 1
The king of Ai, which is near Bethel: 1
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king of Jerusalem: 1
The king of Hebron: 1
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king of Jarmuth: 1
The king of Lachish: 1
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king of Eglon: 1
The king of Gezer: 1
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king of Debir: 1
The king of Geder: 1
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king of Hormah: 1
The king of Arad: 1
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king of Libnah: 1
The king of Adullam: 1
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king of Makkedah: 1
The king of Bethel: 1
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king of Tappuach: 1
The king of Hepher: 1
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king of Aphek: 1
The king of Lasharon: 1
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king of Madon: 1
The king of Hazor: 1
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king of Shimron-meron: 1
The king of Achshaph: 1
verses.speaker: Narrator

The king of Taanach: 1
The king of Megiddo: 1
verses.speaker: Narrator

The king of Kedesh: 1
The king of Jokneam in Carmel: 1
verses.speaker: Narrator

The king of various gentiles in Gilgal: 1
verses.speaker: Narrator
